Videotape is a plastic ribbon, two inches wide,
coated on one side with iron-oxide particles. Like
motion-picture film, it stores sound and moving
pictures; unlike film, it does not have to be chem¬
ically processed before it can be played back. A
few seconds after a scene is recorded on video¬
tape, it can be shown over a television screen.
The difference in quality between the live and
taped performance is virtually undetectable.
Motion-picture film consists of a series of frames
— individual snapshots which, when run at a cer¬
tain speed (twenty-four per second in ordinary
16 mm. motion-picture film), give the visual im¬
pression of continuous motion. On videotape, the
sound and sight consist of hundreds of thousands
of invisible electronic impulses, as many as three
million per second on a single inch of tape.
